First, what IS “UX”?

  • UX stands for User Experience.
  • It is the defining of the Who, Why, What, and How a Product is used.
  • To arrive at these definitions, research and not opinions must be applied.

Things a UX designer may do;

  • Hold workshops with the client to understand goals, objectives and pain-points
  • Run interviews with customers to get an insight into their current experiences and expectations of the clients product or services
  • Create a customer journey (i.e. errr, the journey of a customer)
  • Create a website hierarchy or sitemap (i.e. which pages sit below and next to other pages)
  • Design the product UI (User interface)
  • Work with customers post-purchase, to iteratively improve the UX going forward

So, it’s more than design?

Yes.

Historically someone who “just” designs a website or product might be referred to as a Web Designer or UI (User Interface) designer.

A UI or Web designer is focused on what the user sees and interacts with. Elements like buttons, imagery, navigation, contact form fields etc.

While they may have an understanding of the customer and a deep understanding of design, they are usually less focused on the Who, Why, What, and How.

Why is UX important to my business?

Now you know what UX is, it may be a little clearer why it’s good for your business.

A customer who has a good user experience with your product will have a direct positive emotional connection with you and your business. This leads to increasing trust, repeat business and word-of-mouth recommendations. It breeds satisfaction and the potential for loyalty.

And in the spirit of good UX, listen to research, not opinions…

According to a study by Forester, companies who invest in UX see a lower cost of customer acquisition, lower support cost, increased customer retention, and increased market share. Compared to their peers, the top 10 companies leading in customer experience outperformed the S&P index with close to triple the returns. The research also shows that, on average, every dollar invested in UX brings 100 dollars in return. That’s an ROI of a whopping 9,900 percent. — Atishay Goyal, uxdesign.cc
